_comment: FY2024 Survey Answer Schema - stores only answers, questions are in template
_savings: ~67% space reduction vs full markdown files

engagement_grid._comment: G1: Who was engaged and how

disparities_assessment.other_methods: A survey was distributed during a community event. We also posted the survey on social media. We would like to obtain at lest 50 more responses so that we can generalize the results to identify the needs in the community. From this data we will conduct community listening sessions and determine health outcomes by wealth, how stigma has impacted access to services and if there is a lack of diversity among providers.

behavioral_health_assessment._comment: G3: How behavioral health needs were assessed
behavioral_health_assessment.admin_data_sources: Confidential police reporting and our monthly HUB meeting.
behavioral_health_assessment.barriers: We are anticipating the survey results to identify the gaps r=so tat we can hold a community forum to understand the needs of the community.

practices.name: Developed Survey to gather data from the community

planning.process: Our municipality conducted its own planning process. We contracted a consultant to support this process.

populations_list: Asian, Pacific Islander, or Southeast Asian
Individuals who have been incarcerated and/or under community supervision

how_spent: Expand mobile intervention, treatment, telehealth treatment, and recovery services offered by qualified providers, including recovery coaches
Improve or implement trauma-informed treatment services
Provide transportation to treatment or recovery services for persons with OUD
Support bereaved families and frontline care providers

Support the work of Emergency Medical Systems, including peer support specialists and post-overdose response teams, to connect individuals to trauma-informed treatment recovery support, harm reduction services, primary healthcare, or other appropriate services following an opioid overdose or other opioid-related adverse event

Fund services or training to encourage early identification and intervention for families, children, or adolescents who may be struggling with use of drugs or mental health conditions, including peer-based programs and Youth Mental Health First Aid.

Increase availability of naloxone and other drugs that treat overdoses for first responders, overdose patients, individuals with OUD and their friends and family, schools, community-based organizations, community navigators and outreach workers, persons being released from jail or prison, or the public

Promote efforts to train health care providers, students, peer recovery coaches, recovery outreach specialists, or other professionals that provide care to persons who use opioids or persons with OUD in crisis training and harm reduction strategies
Active outreach strategies such as the Drug Abuse Response Team model or the Post Overdose Support Team model

Programs, that connect individuals involved in the criminal justice system and upon release from jail or prison to OUD harm reduction services, treatment, recovery support, healthcare, prevention, legal support, or other supports, or that provide these
Co-responder and/or alternative responder models to address OUD-related greater OUD expertise

Participate in membership organizations such as the Police Assisted Addiction Recovery Initiative for training and networking and utilize law enforcement opportunities such as the Safety and Health Integration in the Enforcement of Laws on Drugs (SHIELD)
Initiated or expanded FIRST Steps Together or similar evidence-based home visiting program for parents in recovery

additional_comments.unmet_needs: We hope to develop a strategic plan to meet the needs of the community
additional_comments.orrf_recommendations: We will develop a plan that is informed by best practice and the voice of the effected population and their families. Our hope is to identify the gaps and meet the needs in the community.
